ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learnt how to critically read a text and different theoretical frameworks to view fiction through. The novels we read were incredible and very well chosen.
I learned more about the politics behind postcolonial literature, as well as ways to read and think about these texts.
I gained really powerful and radical insight into postcolonial literature and theory. I also became a better writer.

This class has quite honestly changed how I view the world. I have learned so much about post-colonial theory, the politics of language and naming, asked question about what it means to study "English" or to brand a world literature "Anglophone," and so much more. I've also improved as a writer and learned how to better interpret really complicated theoretical readings. Such an amazing, eye-opening class!
I learned how to critically digest research and write academic papers in my own style.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: without doubt the strength of this course is Steph. She is the type of Professor you genuinely look forward to seeing every class. The material is interesting but the way Steph facilitates class discussion is so so so informative. She pushes you to think critically and creatively about texts. While I had read some of these novels prior to the class, I gained a completely new perspective on them. 

Weaknesses: I could not name a weakness in this course. It is a book a week but the readings are so fascinating this is not a problem.
I wish this course gave a set schedule for the reading so that it would be more structured. I really liked the discussion posts that we had to make.

This was an outstanding course, truly one of the best I've taken at Yale. The reading list, Professor Newell, the small class size, the other students in the class, and the assignments were all geared towards engaging critically with the material. The only weakness was just sometimes I felt there was too much reading and I didn't have time to complete all of it, even though I badly wanted to.

Steph is the best professor EVER! Such a strength  the readings are FANTASTIC! And discussions are so much fun, too. Our class was also so brilliant that I learned so much from my classmates, too. The only sort of downside is that sometimes the readings are super long - that being said you feel so accomplished looking back and seeing how much you've done!!

The main strength of this course is that Steph really cares about her students and the topic, and she encourages us to go above and beyond in our thinking. Personally, I felt more intellectually alive than I ever had with another course, and it's all thanks to Steph and her awesome syllabus. One weakness is the sometimes stifling political tangents that some students can go on not every student in the class has the same opinions, and since some of our discussions were built upon assumptions that I fundamentally disagreed with, it was sometimes difficult to participate since I didn't want to throw off the harmony of the class. But these were small occurrences, and overall I loved the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the discussion posts on canvas were a large success. I think if there was a way we could upload voice recording instead this would be more helpful as I process things verbally. The Zoom behaviour though was great and I think Steph was always very adaptable.
I think the seminar worked out well - it was easy to keep the conversation going and not talk over each other.
The virtual seminars worked well! And Steph was so understanding with deadlines, which was so wonderful.
The Zoom seminar format was fine, even when we had individual wifi issues. Better in person for sure, but I have no complaints.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!!! I cannot tell you how much you should take this course. The novels are very interesting but Steph makes this course a must take. It is without doubt the best class I have taken at Yale purely because of her. She just cares so much about her students and is so brilliant. Every one on one interaction with her has further confirmed her kindness and just immense intellect. Before you get to Yale I think there are always stories of incredible professors and she is one of them. She has single handedly reversed my cynicism surrounding Yale faculty. If you are even remotely interested in fiction please please please take this class.
Yes if you have even a slight interest in literature. I had never studied postcolonial literature and this was a very good introduction to the field.
I would recommend this to every student at Yale! You read some excellent books and theorists and critically exam almost all systems of oppression.

YES! it is a fantastic class. even if you're not an English major, Steph alone makes taking the class worth it! I'm a global and English double major, and it has really informed my view of "global affairs" and what I'm doing in post-colonial contexts.
Yes definitely especially with Professor Newell

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
